Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 218,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 218, Section 21.

Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186,.proposition: Plaintiff hereby asserts a claim against Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Plaintiff hereby asserts a claim against Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion directly involves a tenant counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and notes that the Housing Court found in favor of the tenant on that counterclaim. However, the Supreme Judicial Court ultimately affirms on other grounds (retaliation and Chapter 93A) and does not analyze or discuss the elements of a § 14 quiet enjoyment claim in any detail. Thus, the case shows that such a claim is cognizable under Massachusetts law in this landlord-tenant context, but it is not strong authority on the substance of that cause of action.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action... the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 14 (1990 ed.); ... After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims... We now affirm.

Kobayashi v. Orion Ventures, Inc., 42 Ma.raw_text: Kobayashi v. Orion Ventures, Inc., 42 Mass.App.Ct. 492 (1997)
Kobayashi v. Orion Ventures, Inc., 42 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff hereby asserts a claim against Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Kobayashi v. Orion Ventures, Inc., 42 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial lease dispute focused on breach of a noncompetition clause and related damages, summary process, and Chapter 93A issues. It does not discuss, apply, or even mention the Massachusetts covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it analyze landlord interference with possession under that doctrine. Therefore, it provides no authority for a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Kobayashi v. Orion Ventures, Inc., 42 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The tenant was first at the bar with a complaint asking for a declaratory judgment (that under the lease it was entitled to protection from the landlord against Caffé Presto); injunctive relief against Caffé Presto; damages for breach of contract (the noncompetition clause); and unfair or deceptive practices within the meaning of G. L. c. 93A, § 11.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 9.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1980)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 9.proposition: Plaintiff hereby asserts a claim against Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 9.support_reasoning: The case excerpt has nothing to do with a covenant of quiet enjoyment or Massachusetts landlord-tenant law. It involves a dispute in Probate Court over enforcement of a separation agreement and retirement-plan related payments, and the opinion addresses subject-matter jurisdiction and contract remedies. Therefore it does not provide authority for a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 9.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff seeks to recover money due her under a contract in writing. This classically calls for an action at law. The Probate Court has no jurisdiction of actions at law. ... This is an unadorned action in contract which is not cognizable under the general or statutory equity jurisdiction which reposes in the Probate Court. The plaintiff’s remedy at law is plain and complete as well as adequate within the meaning of G. L. c. 214, § 1A."

O'Brien v. Pearson, 449 Mass. 377 (2007).proposition: Plaintiff hereby asserts a claim against Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
O'Brien v. Pearson, 449 Mass. 377 (2007).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a shareholder dispute in a closely held corporation and addresses breach of fiduciary duty among shareholders, standards for directed verdicts, and damages. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, possession of real property, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. Therefore, it provides no authority for a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
O'Brien v. Pearson, 449 Mass. 377 (2007).relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff, Kevin O’Brien, brought this claim against John Pearson and Margaret Palm (defendants), his fellow shareholders in the closely held corporation Summerhill Estates, Inc., for breach of fiduciary duty. ... As shareholders in a close corporation, the parties owed each other a fiduciary duty of the ‘utmost good faith and loyalty.’"

Boston Hous. Authy. v. Blanco, 12 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns statutory salary-continuation and disability benefits for a special police officer under G.L. c. 41, §111F; G.L. c. 32, §85H; and indemnification for medical expenses under G.L. c. 41, §100. It does not mention, analyze, or apply the Massachusetts covenant of quiet enjoyment (typically under G.L. c. 186, §14 or common law landlord-tenant doctrine). Therefore it cannot serve as authority for a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Authy. v. Blanco, 12 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff… seeks… to have the defendant town indemnify him for medical expenses under G. L. c. 41, § 100, and provide him salary continuation benefits under G. L. c. 41, § 111F, and G. L. c. 32, § 85H. The defendants appeal from a “judgment” which awarded benefits under the latter two statutes, annulled the decision of the selectmen denying benefits under G. L. c. 41, § 100, and ordered the selectmen to reconsider the application….

Lawrence v. Concord, 439 Mass. 416 (2008.proposition: Plaintiff hereby asserts a claim against Defendant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Lawrence v. Concord, 439 Mass. 416 (2008.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns adverse possession and an eminent domain taking under G.L. c. 79; it does not involve landlord–tenant relations or any discussion of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. There is no analysis or holding about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, making this case inapposite to the stated proposition.
Lawrence v. Concord, 439 Mass. 416 (2008.relevant_excerpt: "Lawrence brought an action for damages under G. L. c. 79, § 14. ... We conclude that the town’s lack of knowledge as to its ownership did not defeat Frazier’s claim of title by adverse possession, and remand to the Superior Court for a determination of the damages owed to Lawrence arising from the town’s eminent domain proceeding."

81 Spooner Road, LLC v. Colchester, 83 M.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with modification of child support, attribution of income, expert testimony, and Rule 60(b) relief in a domestic relations context. It does not mention, analyze, or apply the covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord-tenant law, or any related property or leasehold concepts. Therefore it cannot provide authority for a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
81 Spooner Road, LLC v. Colchester, 83 M.relevant_excerpt: The child support guidelines allow a judge to attribute income to a party when a finding is made that the party is earning less than he or she could through reasonable efforts. See Massachusetts Child Support Guidelines § II-H (2009)... In sum, we conclude that the matter must be remanded to the Probate and Family Court for further fact finding on the issue of attribution of income, with particular attention paid to whether the wife exercised reasonable efforts in her job search.

Pendergast v. Atrium GGF Corp., 86 Mass..relevant_excerpt: This is an appeal from an Appellate Tax Board (board) decision upholding the denial by the Commissioner of Revenue (commissioner) of a request for an abatement of double taxes assessed to George and Sandra Schussel (Schussels) for filing false or fraudulent income tax returns for the calendar years 1993, 1994, and 1995 (tax years at issue). The case presents three issues: first, whether the board erred as a matter of law in upholding the commissioner’s double tax assessment...
